summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Sarah Coyne and federal prosecutors regarding a planned motion for sentence reduction for an unnamed client. The client attempted to cooperate with the SDNY investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death. The email discusses reviewing the motion draft and potential coordination with the EDNY AUSA.

persons.name: Sarah Coyne
persons.context: Attorney communicating with federal prosecutors about filing a motion for sentence reduction for her client, who attempted to cooperate with the SDNY Epstein death investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of a death investigation by the SDNY, which the attorney's client attempted to cooperate with.

connections.description: Sarah Coyne is preparing a motion for sentence reduction for her client, who attempted to cooperate with the SDNY Epstein investigation.
The client attempted to cooperate with the SDNY investigation into the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Email Correspondence on Sentence Reduction Motion
events.description: Email exchange regarding the preparation and review of a motion to have an unnamed individual's sentence reduced, citing their attempted cooperation with the SDNY Epstein death investigation.

events.title: SDNY Investigation into Epstein's Death
events.description: Reference to an investigation by the Southern District of New York (SDNY) into the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death.

keyFacts: An unnamed individual, represented by attorney Sarah Coyne, attempted to cooperate with the SDNY investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death.
Sarah Coyne was preparing a motion for a sentence reduction for her client based on this attempted cooperation.
The correspondence shows coordination between defense counsel and federal prosecutors (SDNY and EDNY AUSA) regarding the motion.
The motion was intended to be filed under seal.
The prosecutors clarified they did not rely on the information provided by the client in investigating or charging the case.
